entry.title: ATcoder ARC188C 题解
entry.content:
[link](C - Honest or Liar or Confused)

题意

共有 NNN 个人，各具有两个属性：糊涂与否、撒谎与否。现给出 MMM 条指认关系形如：“AAA 认为 BBB 是/否撒谎”。上述指认关系满足：

  • 若发出者不糊涂且不撒谎，那么指认为真（符合事实，即“说真话”）。
  • 若发出者糊涂且不撒谎，那么指认为假（不符合事实，即“说假话”）。
  • 若发出者不糊涂且撒谎，那么指认为假（不符合事实，即“说假话”）。
  • 若发出者糊涂且撒谎，那么指认为真（符合事实，即“说真话”）。

其实就是说：如果发出指认关系的人撒谎，就想说假话，否则就会想说真话~~（废话）~~，如果他糊涂的话就会使这句话变成反话。

根据这些关系推出每个人是否糊涂，求任意一个可行解，或报告无解。

分析

我们先记糊涂与否这个变量为 C=1/0C=1/0C=1/0，撒谎与否这个变量为 L=1/0L=1/0L=1/0。

观察题目，可以看出每条关系都表示了两个布尔变量的取值关系，但是比较复杂，我们要简化这些关系！

考虑记 T=1T=1T=1 是“说真话”，T=0T=0T=0 是“说假话”。那么四种情况的指认关系立马简化为两种。

  • 若发出者说真话，那么指认为真。
  • 若发出者说假话，那么指认为假。

（又是废话）

那么对于一条指认关系，“AAA 认为 BBB 撒谎”，有这些关系：

  • BBB 撒谎（LB=1L_B=1LB​=1）与 AAA 说真话（TA=1T_A=1TA​=1）互为充要条件。
  • BBB 不撒谎（LB=0L_B=0LB​=0）与 AAA 说假话（TA=0T_A=0TA​=0）互为充要条件。

表达了关系：LBL_BLB​ 与 TAT_ATA​ 取值相同。若是“AAA 认为 BBB 不撒谎”，则说明 LBL_BLB​ 与 TAT_ATA​ 取值不同。

题目信息转化为了一堆布尔变量两两之间的取值关系，且只有在 TTT 与 LLL 之间连边。一眼 2-SAT 可做！

我们对于一个人建出 444 个点：L,¬L,T,¬TL,\neg L,T,\neg TL,¬L,T,¬T，表示 L=1/0,T=1/0L=1/0,T=1/0L=1/0,T=1/0 并且根据上述转化连边。

对于一条指认关系，“AAA 认为 BBB 撒谎”，连这些边：

  • TA→LBT_A\rarr L_BTA​→LB​
  • LB→TAL_B\rarr T_ALB​→TA​
  • ¬TA→¬LB\neg T_A\rarr \neg L_B¬TA​→¬LB​
  • ¬LB→¬TA\neg L_B\rarr \neg T_A¬LB​→¬TA​

我们就限制了 TAT_ATA​ 与 LBL_BLB​ 取值相同。

同理连剩下 “AAA 认为 BBB 不撒谎” 的边（不清楚可见代码），跑完 2-SAT 后就知道了 T,LT,LT,L 的取值。

我们可以通过 T,LT,LT,L，反推出题目要求的 CCC。

具体来说，只要同时满足 L\and T 或者 \neg L \and \neg T（撒谎但说真话或者不撒谎但说假话），则可以说这个人满足 C=1C=1C=1，否则 C=0C=0C=0。

注意啦！LLL 与 TTT 的取值是相互独立的，不会互相影响（因为 CCC 并未确定，而每个 L,TL,TL,T 取值的可能都对应一个 CCC 的取值）。所以解矛盾当且仅当：存在 iii 有 TTT 与 ¬T\neg T¬T 同时成立或 LLL 与 ¬L\neg L¬L。

赛时AC记录：Submission #60128360（码风注意，垃圾实现注意，下方的代码已经编辑过了码风orz）

Code: （代码中与上述分析略有不同，将 ¬T\neg T¬T 的点记为 F、将 ¬L\neg L¬L 的点记为 H）

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
typedef long long ll;
typedef long double Lf;
typedef double lf;
const int N = 1e6 + 5, M = 1e6 + 5;
int n, m;
int h[N], ec = -1;
struct Ed
{
	int to, nxt;
} ed[M];
void add(int fr, int to)// 前向星连边
{
	ec++;
	ed[ec] = {to, h[fr]};
	h[fr] = ec;
}
bool T_[N], L_[N];// 记录答案
// 下面四个函数实现了将一个对象建成四个点
int T(int x) { return (x - 1) * 4; }	 //"true"
int F(int x) { return (x - 1) * 4 + 1; } //"false"
int L(int x) { return (x - 1) * 4 + 2; } //"liar"
int H(int x) { return (x - 1) * 4 + 3; } //"honest"
void sta(int x) // 用于统计，将拆开的点记录的信息分开记录
{
	switch (x % 4)
	{
		case 0:
		{
			T_[x / 4 + 1] = true;
			break;
		}
		case 1:
		{
			T_[x / 4 + 1] = false;
			break;
		}
		case 2:
		{
			L_[x / 4 + 1] = true;
			break;
		}
		case 3:
		{
			L_[x / 4 + 1] = false;
			break;
		}
	}
}
int dfn[N], low[N], pvt = 0, sc = 0, s[N];
bool instk[N];
stack<int> S;
void Tarjan(int cur) // Tarjan 缩点
{
	dfn[cur] = low[cur] = ++pvt;
	S.push(cur);
	instk[cur] = true;
	for (int i = h[cur]; i != -1; i = ed[i].nxt)
	{
		int v = ed[i].to;
		if (!dfn[v])
		{
			Tarjan(v);
			low[cur] = min(low[cur], low[v]);
		}
		else if (instk[v])
		{
			low[cur] = min(low[cur], dfn[v]);
		}
	}
	if (low[cur] == dfn[cur])
	{
		sc++;
		while (!S.empty())
		{
			s[S.top()] = sc;
			instk[S.top()] = false;
			if (S.top() == cur)
			{
				S.pop();
				break;
			}
			S.pop();
		}
	}
}
int main()
{
	memset(h, -1, sizeof(h));
	scanf("%d%d", &n, &m);
	for (int i = 1; i <= m; i++)
	{
		int u, v, w;
		scanf("%d%d%d", &u, &v, &w);// 将每个点拆为四个点 T,F,L,H 分别表示 T=1,T=0,L=1,L=0
		if (w == 1)
		{
			add(T(u),L(v));
			add(L(v),T(u));
			add(F(u),H(v));
			add(H(v),F(u));
		}
		else
		{
			add(T(u),H(v));
			add(H(v),T(u));
			add(F(u),L(v));
			add(L(v),F(u));
		}
	}
	int cnt = H(n);// 偷懒的写法，记录了拆点后的点数
	for (int i = 0; i <= cnt; i++)// 考虑 2-SAT，Tarjan 缩点求拓扑序
	{
		if (!dfn[i]) // 对于每个连通块都要缩点
		{
			Tarjan(i);
		}
	}
	bool acce = true;
	for (int i = 0; i <= cnt; i++)
	{
		if (s[i] == s[i ^ 1])// 同时取到某个变量的两个值，布尔方程组无解
		{
			acce = false;
			break;
		}
		if (s[i] > s[i ^ 1]) // 用较小拓扑序的取值方案更新答案，注意标号是反拓扑序
		{
			sta(i);
		}
	}
	if (!acce)
	{
		printf("-1\n");
		return 0;
	}
	for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++)// 通过已知信息求取 C 的取值
	{
		if ((T_[i] && L_[i]) || (!T_[i] && !L_[i]))// 老实人说假话，大骗子讲真话，倒反天罡
			putchar('1');
		else
			putchar('0');
	}
	putchar('\n');
	return 0;
}

entry.title: 呼吸作用
entry.content:
标记

\(\ce{C3H4O3,CH3COCOOH}\): 丙酮酸

\(\ce{[H]}\): 还原氢指的是各种有还原性的辅酶/氢离子

\(\ce{NADH,NADPH}\): 还原型辅酶(Ⅰ/Ⅱ).

\(\ce{NAD+,NADP+}\): 氧化型辅酶(Ⅰ/Ⅱ), \(\ce{NADH,NADPH}\) 氧化后的产物.

\(\ce{FADH2}\): 一种还原型辅酶, 由于有两个氢原子, 表示为 \(\ce{2[H]}\).

\(\ce{FAD}\): \(\ce{FADH2}\) 对应的氧化型辅酶, 氧化性比较强.

\(\ce{ATP,GTP}\): 腺苷三磷酸, 鸟苷三磷酸

\(\ce{ADP,GDP}\): 腺苷二磷酸, 鸟苷二磷酸

\(\ce{Pi}\): 磷酸分子

\(\ce{CoA}\): 辅酶A.

\(\ce{Acetyl-CoA}\): 乙酰辅酶A, 其中包含了一个乙酰基团 \(\ce{CH3CO -}\).

\(\ce{C3}\): 三碳化合物, 3-磷酸甘油酸 (\(\ce{3-PGA}\))

\(\ce{C_5}\): 五碳化合物, 核酮糖-1,5-二磷酸核酮糖 (\(\ce{RuBP}\))

有氧呼吸

阶段1: 糖酵解

场所: 细胞质基质.

放出少量能量.

糖酵解指的是葡萄糖 (\(\ce{C6H12O6}\)) 转化为丙酮酸 (\(\ce{C3H4O3}\)) 的过程.
\[\ce{C6H12O6 + 2NAD+ + 2ADP +2Pi-> 2C3H4O3 +2NADH +2H+ +2ATP +2H2O}\]
这里的 \(\ce{NADH}\) 和 \(\ce{H+}\) 被看做还原氢.

简化后的式子:
\[\ce{C6H12O6-> 2C3H4O3 + 4[H]}\]

阶段2: 丙酮酸脱羧+三羧酸循环

场所: 线粒体基质.

消耗水. 放出少量能量. 放出二氧化碳.

丙酮酸脱羧过程(和上面的式子摩尔量保持一致):
\[\ce{2C3H4O3 + 2NAD+ +2CoA -> 2Acetyl-CoA + 2CO2 +2NADH + 2H+}\]
然后, 乙酰辅酶A参与三羧酸循环(柠檬酸循环), 最终分解为 \(\ce{CO2}\).

三羧酸循环本质是乙酰辅酶A的氧化, 它的起始是乙酰辅酶A与草酰乙酸化合, 在经历了一段循环后又生成了草酰乙酸, 所以这个过程可以源源不断地氧化乙酰辅酶A.
\[\ce{2Acetyl-CoA + 6NAD+ +2FAD +2GDP + 2Pi +4H2O->}\ \ce{4CO2 + 6NADH + 6H+ +2FADH2 + 2GTP + 2CoA}\]
这一步参与反应的是 \(\ce{GDP}\) 而非 \(\ce{ADP}\).

这里的 \(\ce{[H]}\) 指的是 \(\ce{NADH,FADH2,H+}\), 一共得到了 \(\ce{20[H]}\).

简化后的式子:
\[\ce{2C3H4O3 + 6H2O-> 6CO2 + 20[H]}\]

阶段3: 电子传递链(呼吸链)

场所: 线粒体内膜.

消耗氧气. 放出大量能量.

电子传递链是细胞线粒体内膜上一系列通道蛋白和酶的总称.

高能电子在线粒体内膜上经过受体传递电位逐渐降低, 最后质子和氧气结合生成水.

电子传递链(和上面的式子摩尔量保持一致):
\[\ce{10NADH + 10H+ +2FADH2 +26ADP + 26Pi + 6O2->10NAD+ +2FAD +12H2O +26ATP}\]
简化后的式子:
\[\ce{24[H] + 6O2->12H2O}\]

总反应式

\[\ce{C6H12O6 + 6H2O + 6O2 -> 12H2O + 6CO2}\]

经过整个过程, 分解一分子葡萄糖, 总共收获了 \(32\) 个 \(\ce{ATP}\) 与 \(\ce{GTP}\). 真是血赚!

无氧呼吸

没有氧气参与反应, 只在糖酵解阶段产生少量能量.

阶段一: 糖酵解

无氧呼吸的第一阶段都是糖酵解.
\[\ce{C6H12O6 + 2 NAD+ + 2ADP +2Pi→ 2 CH3COCOOH + 2 NADH + 2 ATP + 2 H+}\]

不同途径: 酒精发酵/乳酸发酵

1. 酒精发酵路径 - 阶段二/三: 糖裂解/乙酰还原

例子: 酵母菌.
\[\ce{2CH3COCOOH → 2 CO2 + 2 CH3CHO}\ \ce{2CH3CHO + 2 NADH + 2 H+ → 2 C2H5OH + 2 NAD+}\]
\(\ce{CH3COCOOH}\): 丙酮酸. \(\ce{CH3CHO}\): 乙醛.

丙酮酸脱去羧后生成的是乙醛而不是乙酰辅酶A, 乙酰被 \(\ce{NADH}\) 还原成乙醇.

2. 乳酸发酵路径 - 阶段二: 丙酮酸还原

例子: 骨骼肌、乳酸杆菌.
\[\ce{2 CH3COCOOH + 2 NADH + 2 H+ → 2 CH3CHOHCOOH + 2 NAD+}\]
\(\ce{CH3COCOOH}\): 丙酮酸. \(\ce{CH3CHOHCOOH}\): 乳酸 (\(\ce{C3H6O3}\)).

总反应式

\[\ce{C6H12O6->C2H5OH +CO2}\ \ce{C6H12O6->C3H6O3}\]

定义

不定积分

记号是 ∫f(x)dx\displaystyle\int f(x) dx∫f(x)dx, ddd 符号后面的是自变量.

函数 f(x)f(x)f(x) 的不定积分定义为它的原函数 F(x)F(x)F(x), 满足 F′(x)=f(x)F'(x)=f(x)F′(x)=f(x). 即 F(x)F(x)F(x) 的导数为 f(x)f(x)f(x). 一个函数有多个不定积分, 这是由于相差一个常数 CCC 的函数的导数是一致的, 即 F(x)F(x)F(x) 与任意的 F(x)+CF(x)+CF(x)+C 都是 f(x)f(x)f(x) 的原函数.

定积分

函数 f(x)f(x)f(x) 在闭区间 [a,b][a,b][a,b] 上的定积分定义为自变量 xxx 取值居于 [a,b][a,b][a,b] 时, 函数的积分和的极限.

几何意义上来说, 是函数 f(x)f(x)f(x) 在 [a,b][a,b][a,b] 上取值为正的部分图象下方的面积减去取值负的部分图象上方的面积.

记号是 ∫abf(x)dx\displaystyle\int^{b}_{a}f(x)dx∫ab​f(x)dx, 其中 aaa 是积分下界, bbb 是积分上界.

有极限定义:

∫abf(x)dx=lim⁡n→+∞∑i−1nb−an⋅f[a+in(b−a)]\displaystyle\int_{a}^{b}f(x)dx=\lim_{n\rightarrow+\infty}\sum_{i-1}^{n}\frac{b-a}{n}\cdot f\left[a+\frac{i}{n}(b-a)\right] ∫ab​f(x)dx=n→+∞lim​i−1∑n​nb−a​⋅f[a+ni​(b−a)]

恰好, 如果区间为 [0,1][0,1][0,1]:

∫01f(x)dx=lim⁡n→+∞∑i=1n1nf(in)\displaystyle\int^{1}_{0} f(x)dx=\lim_{n\rightarrow+\infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\dfrac{1}{n}{f\left(\dfrac{i}{n}\right)} ∫01​f(x)dx=n→+∞lim​i=1∑n​n1​f(ni​)

* 定积分与不定积分的区别在于, 前者的运算结果是函数, 而后者是数值.

牛顿-莱布尼茨公式

如果 f(x)f(x)f(x) 在 [a,b][a,b][a,b] 连续可积, 有原函数(不定积分) F(x)F(x)F(x).

那么有

∫abf(x)dx=F(b)−F(a)=F(x)∣ab\displaystyle\int_{a}^{b}f(x)dx=F(b)-F(a)=\left.F(x)\right|_{a}^{b} ∫ab​f(x)dx=F(b)−F(a)=F(x)∣ab​

基本性质

1. 积分有可加性.

具体来说, 对于定积分 ∫ab[f(x)+g(x)]dx\displaystyle\int_{a}^{b}[f(x)+g(x)]dx∫ab​[f(x)+g(x)]dx, 有:

∫ab[f(x)±g(x)]dx=∫abf(x)dx±∫abg(x)dx\displaystyle\int_{a}^{b}\left[f(x)\pm g(x)\right]dx=\displaystyle\int_{a}^{b} f(x)dx\pm\displaystyle\int_{a}^{b}g(x)dx ∫ab​[f(x)±g(x)]dx=∫ab​f(x)dx±∫ab​g(x)dx

不定积分同理.

2. 积分的常系数可以提到积分号前.

形式化地:

∫abkf(x)dx=k∫abf(x)dx\displaystyle\int_{a}^{b}kf(x)dx=k\displaystyle\int_{a}^{b}f(x)dx ∫ab​kf(x)dx=k∫ab​f(x)dx

  1. 当 a=ba=ba=b 时, ∫abf(x)dx=0\displaystyle\int_{a}^{b}f(x)dx=0∫ab​f(x)dx=0.

  2. 当 a>ba>ba>b 时, ∫abf(x)dx=−∫baf(x)dx\displaystyle\int_{a}^{b}f(x)dx=-\displaystyle\int_{b}^{a}f(x)dx∫ab​f(x)dx=−∫ba​f(x)dx, 这是人为定义的.

  3. 如果 f(x)f(x)f(x) 在区间 DDD 上可积, 那么对于 a,b,c∈Da,b,c\in Da,b,c∈D, 有:

entry.content:
Me: I had a new question about diffusion phenomenon.

A U-shaped pipe containing a piece of semipermeable membrane in the middle part of it is now filled up with two types of solutions. The left side is filled up with glucose solution, while the right side is filled up with sucrose solution. We define that they are of the same volume and mass fraction(not molarity, instead, the same mass).

Now explain what will happen under the following two circumstances:

  • The semipermeable membrane allows water and glucose to go across itself.
  • The semipermeable membrane allows water to go across itself.

Just state it simply with the facts of diffusion phenomenon.

GPT-4o:

Let's break down what would happen in each case based on the principles of diffusion and osmosis.

  1. When the membrane allows water and glucose to pass through:

    • Water and glucose molecules can both move across the membrane, so they will tend to diffuse towards the side with lower concentrations of water or glucose until equilibrium is reached.
    • Since both sides start with equal volumes and mass fractions of glucose and sucrose, water movement will likely be minimal.
    • Glucose molecules will diffuse from the side with a higher concentration of glucose to the side with lower glucose concentration until they are evenly distributed on both sides.
    • Sucrose cannot pass, so it remains in place, meaning that glucose alone equalizes across both sides, while sucrose concentration remains different.

  2. When the membrane allows only water to pass:

    • Water molecules will diffuse across the membrane to balance the osmotic pressure difference caused by the presence of sucrose and glucose.
    • Since sucrose cannot pass, it creates a higher osmotic pressure on the sucrose side, drawing water towards it.
    • This will lead to water moving from the glucose side to the sucrose side, increasing the volume of the sucrose solution side and decreasing the volume on the glucose side.
    • Glucose and sucrose concentrations will change due to this water movement, but they won’t diffuse across the membrane since glucose cannot move to the sucrose side in this setup.

Me:

Okay, but I guess I am confused.

Q1: How do the diffusion works? Does it depend on molarity or mass fraction? Or I am going to ask, "If a piece of membrane has solutions of the same mass fraction or of the same molarity(but of different solutes) on its two sides. Only water moves. What is the result respectively?"

Q2: What if membrane allows solutes to pass? Am I going to say sucrose solution is also solvent as it allows glucose to dissolve?

GPT-4o:

Great questions! Diffusion and osmosis can be tricky, especially when considering concentration measures like mass fraction and molarity. Let’s go through each of these concepts to clarify.

Q1: How does diffusion work? Does it depend on molarity or mass fraction?

Diffusion depends primarily on molarity rather than mass fraction. Here’s why:

  1. Diffusion and Molarity: Diffusion is driven by concentration gradients in terms of particles (molecules or ions). Molarity measures concentration based on the number of moles per unit volume of solution, which reflects how many particles are present. Particles diffuse from areas of high molarity (high particle concentration) to areas of low molarity until equilibrium is reached.

  2. Mass Fraction: Mass fraction (or mass percentage) measures the amount of solute relative to the total mass of the solution. However, different solutes have different molar masses, so equal mass fractions do not correspond to equal numbers of particles.

For example, a glucose solution and a sucrose solution of the same mass fraction will not have the same molarity because sucrose molecules are heavier than glucose molecules. This means they don’t have the same number of particles per liter of solution, so diffusion would occur based on the molarity difference.

Scenario Analysis with Water Movement Only

If the semipermeable membrane only allows water to pass and you have solutions with:

  • Equal Mass Fractions: Water will move from the side with the lower molarity to the side with the higher molarity (i.e., towards the side with fewer molecules per unit volume).

  • Equal Molarities: If both sides have the same molarity (the same particle concentration) but different solutes, no net water movement will occur. This is because the osmotic pressures are balanced as each side has an equal number of particles.

Q2: What if the membrane allows solutes to pass?

If the membrane allows both solutes to pass (in this case, glucose and sucrose), diffusion of the solutes will occur across the membrane:

  1. Direction of Movement: Glucose and sucrose will each diffuse according to their concentration gradients until equilibrium is reached on both sides. Both solutes will spread across the membrane until their individual molarities equalize on both sides.

  2. Solvent-Solute Relationship: In solutions, water is typically considered the primary solvent. However, if glucose and sucrose are able to pass through the membrane, we could think of them as dissolving in each other’s solutions. In this sense, the term “solvent” refers more broadly to the ability of one substance (water) to dissolve both glucose and sucrose, facilitating the movement of particles across the membrane. However, sucrose doesn't become a solvent in a strict chemical sense; it simply diffuses into the space, mixing with water and glucose to equalize concentrations.

In summary:

  • Diffusion relies on molarity (number of particles), not mass fraction.
  • Water movement depends on osmotic pressure differences, which relate to molarity.
  • When solutes can pass, they diffuse individually to balance concentration on both sides, acting as if they “dissolve” in each other’s presence if allowed by the membrane.

Me: Thanks a lot. So in my original questions, which side of the U-shaped pipe will finally has a higher liquid level (for both two circumstances)?

(P.S. I'm going to say, "the same mass fractions" is emphasized.)

GPT-4o:

Let’s go through each case in your original question with the emphasis on "the same mass fractions."

Recap of Key Points:

Since the solutions have the same mass fraction of glucose and sucrose, the molarity (particle concentration) will differ. This is because sucrose molecules are larger and heavier than glucose molecules. Therefore:

  • The sucrose side will have fewer particles (lower molarity) than the glucose side, even though their mass fractions are the same.
  • This difference in particle concentration affects osmotic pressure, which influences the direction of water movement.

Analysis of Liquid Level in Each Case

Case 1: Membrane allows water and glucose to pass

  1. Water Movement: Because both sides have equal mass fractions but different molarities, water will initially tend to move from the lower molarity side (sucrose) to the higher molarity side (glucose) to balance osmotic pressure.

  2. Glucose Movement: Glucose can also diffuse across the membrane. It will tend to move from the glucose-rich side to the sucrose-rich side until it reaches equilibrium.

  3. Final Liquid Levels:

    • Water initially moves towards the glucose side, raising its liquid level.
    • As glucose equilibrates across both sides, the molarity difference reduces, which reduces further water movement.
    • The final liquid levels will likely be similar on both sides due to the balancing effect of both water and glucose movement.

Case 2: Membrane allows only water to pass

  1. Water Movement: Since only water can move and not glucose or sucrose, water will flow from the glucose side (higher molarity) to the sucrose side (lower molarity) due to osmotic pressure differences.

  2. Final Liquid Levels:

    • This water movement will increase the liquid level on the sucrose side and decrease it on the glucose side.
    • Ultimately, the sucrose side will have a higher liquid level as water moves to balance the concentration of particles across the membrane.

Summary:

  • In Case 1 (water and glucose can pass): Both sides will likely end up with similar liquid levels.
  • In Case 2 (only water can pass): The sucrose side will have a higher liquid level due to osmotic movement of water towards the lower molarity side.

Me: Hey, I guess you are wrong! Water goes to higher molarity side!

GPT-4o:

You’re absolutely right, and I apologize for the oversight! Water indeed moves toward the side with the higher molarity (higher concentration of solute particles), not the lower. Let’s correct the explanation based on this:

Corrected Analysis of Liquid Levels

Since the glucose and sucrose solutions have equal mass fractions but different molarities (glucose side having a higher molarity due to smaller molecule size), the osmotic pressure will be higher on the glucose side. Thus, water will flow toward the glucose side in both cases.

Revised Results for Each Case

Case 1: Membrane allows both water and glucose to pass

  1. Water Movement: Water moves towards the glucose side because it has a higher osmotic pressure due to the higher particle concentration.

  2. Glucose Movement: Glucose will also diffuse from the glucose side to the sucrose side until equilibrium is reached.

  3. Final Liquid Levels:

    • Initially, water will raise the liquid level on the glucose side.
    • As glucose diffuses across to equalize its concentration, the osmotic pressure difference diminishes, stabilizing the water movement.
    • Ultimately, both sides may end up with similar liquid levels due to the combined effect of water and glucose diffusion balancing out.

Case 2: Membrane allows only water to pass

  1. Water Movement: Water moves from the sucrose side (lower molarity) toward the glucose side (higher molarity).

  2. Final Liquid Levels:

    • Since glucose cannot move, the osmotic pressure difference remains, so water will continue moving to the glucose side.
    • The glucose side will end up with a higher liquid level.

Corrected Summary:

  • In Case 1 (water and glucose can pass): The liquid levels will likely stabilize and be similar on both sides.
  • In Case 2 (only water can pass): The glucose side will have a higher liquid level as water continues moving toward it due to its higher molarity.

Thanks for catching that error!

entry.title: Na2Sx
entry.content:
\(\ce{Na2S_{x}}\) Catastrophe

Me: \(\ce{Na2S_{x}}\) can be oxidized by \(\ce{NaClO}\) and turn into \(\ce{Na2SO4}\) in alkaline solution. Additionally, \(\ce{NaClO}\) is reduced, and turns into \(\ce{NaCl}\). If the ratio of \(\ce{Na2S_{x}}\) and \(\ce{NaClO}\) is known as \(1:10\). Is it possible to find \(x\)? If it is, what is the value of \(x\)?

GPT-4o:

Yes, it is possible to find \(x\), which represents the number of sulfur atoms in the polysulfide ion (\( \ce{S_x^{2-}} \)), using the provided information.

Given that the reaction involves the oxidation of \(\ce{Na2S_x}\) to \( \ce{Na2SO4} \), we can write the half-reaction for the oxidation of polysulfide:

\[\ce{S_x^{2-} -> SO4^{2-} + (x-1)S^{0} + 8e^-}\]
Here, \( x-1 \) sulfur atoms are released as elemental sulfur, and one sulfur atom from \( \ce{S_x^{2-}} \) is oxidized to sulfate (\( \ce{SO4^{2-}} \)).

For the reduction of hypochlorite (\( \ce{ClO^-} \)) to chloride (\( \ce{Cl^-} \)) in an alkaline solution:

\[\ce{ClO^- + 2e^- + H2O -> Cl^- + 2OH^-}\]
Now, to balance the overall redox reaction, consider the stoichiometric relationship between \( \ce{Na2S_x} \) and \( \ce{NaClO} \). You are told that the ratio of \( \ce{Na2S_x} \) to \( \ce{NaClO} \) is \(1:10\), meaning one molecule of \( \ce{Na2S_x} \) reacts with ten molecules of \( \ce{NaClO} \).

The oxidation of \( \ce{S_x^{2-}} \) involves the transfer of 8 electrons, while the reduction of one \( \ce{ClO^-} \) consumes \(2\) electrons. Therefore, the number of \( \ce{ClO^-} \) molecules required to balance the oxidation of one \( \ce{S_x^{2-}} \) ion is:

\[\frac{8}{2} = 4\]
However, the given ratio is \(1:10\), which indicates that the oxidation of one \( \ce{S_x^{2-}} \) ion requires \(10\) molecules of \( \ce{ClO^-} \). This means the number of electrons transferred in the oxidation of \( \ce{S_x^{2-}} \) is actually:

\[2 \times 10 = 20 \text{ electrons}\]

Since each \( \ce{S_x^{2-}} \) ion releases \(8\) electrons during oxidation, we can set up the equation:

\[8x = 20\]

Solving for \( x \):

\[x = \frac{20}{8} = 2.5\]

Thus, \( x = 2.5 \).

This suggests that the polysulfide ion is likely a mixture of \( \ce{S_2^{2-}} \) and \( \ce{S_3^{2-}} \) or that it has a fractional stoichiometry in this context, which can occur in complex polysulfide mixtures.

大致题意：给出长度为 NNN 的正整数数对序列 (Ai,Bi)⋯(An,Bn)(A_i,B_i)\cdots(A_n,B_n)(Ai​,Bi​)⋯(An​,Bn​), 要求从111 至 NNN 中选取 KKK 个下标组成集合 SSS, 以最小化 (max⁡i∈SAi)×(∑i∈SBi)\left(\max_{i\in S} A_i\right)\times\left(\sum_{i\in S}B_i\right)(maxi∈S​Ai​)×(∑i∈S​Bi​).

观察到整个集合中 AiA_iAi​ 的最大值只取决于最大的一个元素, 而 BiB_iBi​ 之和是取决于所有选取的 KKK 个元素的.

因此考虑将所有数对依照 AiA_iAi​ 为第一关键字排序.

那么选择第 AxA_xAx​ 个元素, 那么就相当于决定 max⁡i∈SAi\max_{i\in S} A_imaxi∈S​Ai​ 为 AxA_xAx​, 问题转化为直接处理 1−x1-x1−x 的前缀 KKK 小值之和, 再总体维护所有的乘积最小值.

考虑如何维护这个前缀 KKK 小值. 既然要刚好选 KKK 个, 首先直接处理前 KKK 个元素, 随后的处理过程中利用堆, 每次加入一个新的 BiB_iBi​, 弹出一个最大元素. 维护堆内元素的和即可 O(nlog⁡n)O(n\log n)O(nlogn) 处理出答案.

Code:

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
typedef long long ll;
typedef long double Lf;
typedef double lf;
const ll N = 2e5 + 5;
ll t;
ll n, k;
ll a[N], b[N];
pair<ll, ll> x[N];
priority_queue<ll> res;
ll sum = 0;
int main()
{
	scanf("%lld", &t);
	while (t--)
	{
		sum = 0;
		ll ans = LLONG_MAX;
		while (!res.empty())
		{
			res.pop();
		}
		scanf("%lld%lld", &n, &k);
		for (ll i = 1; i <= n; i++)
		{
			scanf("%lld", &a[i]);
		}
		for (ll i = 1; i <= n; i++)
		{
			scanf("%lld", &b[i]);
		}
		for (ll i = 1; i <= n; i++)
		{
			x[i].first = a[i];
			x[i].second = b[i];
		}
		sort(x + 1, x + 1 + n);
		for (ll i = 1; i <= k; i++)
		{
			res.push(x[i].second);
			sum += x[i].second;
		}
		ans = x[k].first * sum;
		for (ll i = k + 1; i <= n; i++)
		{
			res.push(x[i].second);
			sum += x[i].second;
			sum -= res.top();
			res.pop();
			ans = min(ans, sum * x[i].first);
		}
		printf("%lld\n", ans);
	}
	return 0;
}
